resources.string: \ CPU Usage\ \ If you leave DroidFish running in the background and GameMode is set to Analysis or Computer vs Computer, or if Thinking Time is set to a large value, or if Pondering is enabled, DroidFish can use a lot of CPU power.\ \ If you are running on battery power, it is recommended that you change settings to conserve battery power, or that you exit DroidFish using the back button when you are not actively using the program.

Failed to initialize text to speech
Text to speech not supported for this language

Network engines let DroidFish connect to a chess engine running on another computer (PC, Mac, or server) over your local network or the internet.

▶ What you need:
• A computer running Chess-UCI-Server (Python)
• A UCI chess engine installed on that computer (e.g. Stockfish)
• Both devices on the same network, or a public IP / port forwarding

▶ Quick start:
1. Download Chess-UCI-Server from:
 github.com/vidar808/Chess-UCI-Server_Droidfish
2. Configure config.json with your engine path and a port (e.g. 8001)
3. Run: python chess.py
4. In DroidFish, tap “New Server”
5. Enter the server’s IP address and port
6. Tap “Test Connection” to verify

▶ Firewall:
You must open the configured port in your computer’s firewall. The server listens on one TCP port per engine.
• Windows: netsh advfirewall firewall add rule name="Chess UCI" dir=in action=allow protocol=TCP localport=8001
• Linux: sudo ufw allow 8001/tcp
• macOS: Add exception in System Settings → Network → Firewall

▶ Optional features:
• TLS encryption — encrypts all traffic between app and server
• Token authentication — prevents unauthorized connections
• QR code pairing — scan a QR code to auto-fill connection settings
• mDNS discovery — tap Discover to find servers on your local network

▶ Troubleshooting:
• "Connection refused" — check the server is running and the port is correct
• "Unknown host" — verify the IP address or hostname
• "Connection timed out" — check firewall rules and that both devices are on the same network
• "Auth failed" — verify the auth token matches the server configuration
You may need to open this port in your firewall
Server requires authentication but none configured. Re-scan QR code.
Invalid QR code (not a chess-uci-server code)
Camera permission is required to scan QR codes
No servers found on local network
Check that the server is running and that port %s is open in the firewall

Show the startup guide the next time the program is started.
To open the left menu, tap on the left side of the title bar or swipe from the left side of the screen towards the right side.
To open the right menu, tap on the right side of the title bar or swipe from the right side of the screen towards the left side.
Touch and hold the chess board to open the tools menu.
Tap a button to invoke its action. Touch and hold a button to open a menu containing secondary actions. To configure button actions go to Left Menu > Settings > Behavior > Configure Buttons.
Tap a move in the move list to set the chess board to the corresponding position. Touch and hold the move list to open the Edit Game menu.
When the engine is thinking, touch and hold the analysis information to open the Analysis menu.
No games found for this position
Set a Lichess username in Settings \u2192 Opening Book to use Player database
Server does not support engine selection

Basic — Default balanced play. All parameters at standard values.

Amanda — Aggressive attacker with high mobility. Prioritizes own attack (150) and mobility (125) over defense.

Ampere — Strong attacker (160) who values pawn structure. Good at creating and exploiting pawn weaknesses.

Cloe — Positional player who likes closed positions. Reduced mobility emphasis, strong pawn chain play.

Deborah — Defensive style, prefers bishops. Lower attack initiative (85) but strong counter-play (115).

Defender — Solid and slightly materialistic (105). Focuses on opponent's attack (110) rather than own initiative.

Grumpy — Aggressive (120 attack) with contempt. Likes blocked positions and restraining the opponent.

Morphy — Romantic sacrificial style. Low material weight (78), high attack (135) and mobility (100). Inspired by Paul Morphy.

Nimzowitsch — Positional restraint and blockade. Lower priority on opponent threats (90), emphasis on outposts. Inspired by Aron Nimzowitsch.

Partisan — Extreme attacker (200) with stealthy openings. Very aggressive but uses quiet opening books.

Pawnsacker — Willing to sacrifice pawns. Low material weight (90), balanced attack and defense.

Pedrita — Pawn-focused and defensive. Strong counter-attack awareness (120), values pawn structure highly.

Preston — Materialistic moderate attacker. Slightly elevated material (110) and attack (105) weights.

Simple — Simplified evaluation with Fruit-style piece tables. Some advanced features disabled for cleaner play.

Spitfire — Balanced with strong counter-attack focus. Standard attack but elevated opponent-attack awareness (150).

Strangler — Extreme aggression (300 attack). Sacrifices material for crushing attacks. Adapted from Rodent III.

Tal — Ultra-aggressive (450 attack). Maximum sacrificial style. Named after Mikhail Tal, the "Magician from Riga".
